descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas dataset contains data on Agricultural Land Coverage on Hydric Soils for each Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) 12-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code (HUC-12) of the conterminous United States that is considered to be both hydric and agricultural based on the December 30, 2009 Natural Resources Conservation Service Soil Survey Geographic Database (NRCS SSURGO), the 2006 National Land Cover Database (NLCD), and the USDA's 2010 Cropland Data Layer (CDL). Because these data are based on SSURGO map units' percent hydric there are four thresholds used to classify if a particular map unit would be hydric. These thresholds are 20%, 40%, 60% and 80%, where a map unit area that had a value of 42% for the SSURGO hydric measurement (based on the raster dataset named "sum_comppct_r2_hydric") would be considered non-hydric under the 60% threshold but hydric under both the 20% and 40% thresholds. For this dataset, the threshold of 80% is used.
This dataset was produced by Tetra Tech, Inc. to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose:
This table allows the user to join the results of hydric soil data analyses for the total drainage area to the WBD HUC-12 GIS file for subsequent display or analysis.
The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.
descript.supplinf:
This EnviroAtlas dataset is based on data originally developed using a version of the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD 2011) extracted for EnviroAtlas on March 22, 2011. In 2015, EnviroAtlas transitioned from the WBD 2011 to a newer version - the National Hydrography Dataset Plus (NHDPlus) V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version - which includes updated 12-digit HUC boundaries for the Conterminous United States.
This EnviroAtlas dataset was created by reallocating the original WBD 2011 dataset to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot using area-weighted reallocation. The area weighting process assumes that values are distributed evenly across HUCs. In cases where values are unevenly distributed within a HUC, this can result in misallocated values in the new dataset. Therefore, users should exercise caution when interpreting this data, especially in regions where there are significant changes to the 12-digit HUCs. The majority of spatial changes between the two 12-digit HUC versions took place along the California coast, in Minnesota, and along the US-Canada border, especially in New England. Metric values for most of the rest of the United States are essentially unchanged. If the user is interested in data for a specific small area, especially in areas that were modified, using the original WBD 2011 version of this dataset joined with the WBD 2011 boundary feature class should provide accurate metric values. As new versions of the dataset are developed using the 2015 HUCs, these will replace the reallocated datasets in EnviroAtlas.
Before reallocating the metrics, edits were made to the area of some 12-digit HUCs. For example, along the coast of California some 12-digit HUCs had stopped at the coastline in the WBD 2011 dataset but were extended into the ocean in the NHDPlus V2 dataset. Instead of reallocating the metrics using the total area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs, the land area based on National Land Cover Database (NLCD) 2011 was used to update the land area values. This ensured the land area of the NHDPlus V2 HUCs roughly matched the land area of the WBD 2011 HUCs. This method helped avoid incorrectly distributing terrestrial metrics, such as including the new ocean-extended area in the denominator of values that were originally calculated using land-only area as the denominator, which would result in artificially lowering the values of per-unit area metrics in the ocean-extended HUCs.

procstep.procdesc: The polygon version of the WBD HUC12 (provided by EPA, ORD, Landscape Ecology Group, March 2011 version) was converted to raster to increase efficiency and accuracy of subsequent runs of "Zonal Stats as Table" processing performed for the EnviroAtlas HUC-12 scale metric outputs. The first processing step was to manually select by bounding HUC-12 units that generally coincided with the CDL raster.

The "Dissolve" tool was run using the field name, "HUC_12," to make multipart features using the GUI of "Dissolve" tool in v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS. This resulted in multipart features for all duplicate "HUC_12" ID's that existed whenever a HUC-12 was not physically connected, such as on certain coast lines and large water bodies. The Dissolve Tool process eliminated the duplicates as rows in a table, but kept the geometry of the features intact.

A "Unique_ID" field was created for the ascending order of "OBJECTID," the primary key in an ESRI ArcGIS geodatabase. This shortened the digits representing an ID from 12 to 5 digits. The ID truncation was necessary for the future processing steps of joining and embedding CDL data into HUC12 ID's in the VALUE field using raster datasets. This process was done using the "AutoIncrement" add-on, v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.

The WBD HUC12 was converted to raster with the "Polygon to Raster" tool in the GUI, v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS. Created using "Unique_ID" as the "Value" field, cell assignment type MAXIMUM_AREA, snapped to the raster "sum_comppct_r2_hydric," Cell size: "sum_comppct_r2_hydric," producing perfect agreement for accurate Zonal Statistics results as well as accurate raster processing with both SSURGO soil layers and the CDL, which both share alignment and cell size.
The NLCD-CDL code in the raster's "Value" field was embedded into the HUC12 raster. Raster calculator: (HUC-12*1000)+CDL.
A Raster Attribute Table was created in v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
"Field Calculator" was used to create two new fields in the HUC12CDL combined raster, "Unique_ID," [([Value] -Right( [Value],3 ))/1000] and "CDL," Right( [Value],3 ). v10.0 of ESRI ArcGIS.
SSURGO "sum_comppct_r2_hydric" was reclassified to make a binary raster with 0 < 20, and 1 >= 20. Reclassify("sum_comppct_r2_hydric", "Value", RemapRange([[0,19,0],[20,100,1]])).
SSURGO "sum_comppct_r2_hydric" was reclassified to make a binary raster with 0 < 40, and 1 >= 40. Reclassify("sum_comppct_r2_hydric", "Value", RemapRange([[0,39,0],[40,100,1]]))
SSURGO "sum_comppct_r2_hydric" was reclassified to make a binary raster with 0 < 60, and 1 >= 60. Reclassify("sum_comppct_r2_hydric", "Value", RemapRange([[0,59,0],[60,100,1]]))
SSURGO "sum_comppct_r2_hydric" was reclassified to make a binary raster with 0 < 80, and 1 >= 80. Reclassify("sum_comppct_r2_hydric", "Value", RemapRange([[0,79,0],[80,100,1]]))

Reclassified binary Hydric_20, 40, 60, 80 Rasters were multiplied against HUC-12 NLCD-CDL coded raster. Raster Calculator: HUC12CDL*Hydric##. Results were 0 for all Hydric values less than the threshold. CDL codes for everything else in each HUC-12 remained.

Tables were exported as .txt files and imported into a Microsoft Access Database. The database summed the total CDL Count for each HUC-12 unit and summed the Count for each CDL code by each HUC-12 unit. The overall sums of every CDL code by each HUC-12 unit were then divided by the total HUC-12 Count, giving a percentage as a decimal. Percentages were calculated by raster cell counts (cell size of 30m x 30m and an area of 900 m2 per raster cell). This dataset contains percentages of land classified as agricultural and hydric using the 80% threshold.
The decimal values were multiplied by 100 to obtain percentage values.
Reallocated values from the original March 22 2011 WBD to the NHDPlus V2 WBD Snapshot, EnviroAtlas version for the Conterminous United States using area-weighted redistribution.

enttyp.enttypd: A table containing the percentage of agricultural land coverage with a hydric soil classification in each HUC12 in the conterminous US, based on a threshold of >= 80 %.

attr.attrdef: Twelve Digit Hydrologic Unit Code. This field provides a unique 12-digit code for each subwatershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined, numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.

overview.eaover:
For more information about EnviroAtlas data, go to https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets.
This dataset contains data on Agricultural Land Coverage for each Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) 12-Digit Hydrological Unit Code (HUC-12) based on the National Land Cover Database (NLCD) and the USDA's Crop Data Layer (CDL). These combined sources provide NLCD land coverages and agricultural land uses. It can be for used for data ranging from >= 80% hydric soil of "sum_comppct_r2_hydric" from the Soil Survey Geographic (SSURGO) Database. Percentages are calculated by raster cell counts; cell size of 30m x 30m and an area of 900 m2 per raster cell.
A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps.
